page.title: 08EDUCATION 1 BISHOP THORNTON
page.content: The Church of England school was built upon a piece of land, part of the wastes of the manor of Thornton, which was given for that purpose by the Archbishop of York to 7 persons as trustees at a rent of 1 shilling a year at a court held on 1st June 1832. The first records we have is in the school log book when the Headmaster, James Moss opened the school in 1873 when 13 boys and 9 girls were on roll. By 1897 the number on roll was 71 children. The school must have been very crowded. There are 25 children on roll at the present day, 1985, Headteacher Mrs. Hazel Stoyles. Assistant Teacher Mrs. Susan Partner. There is also a Roman Catholic School in the village opened in 1861, with 20 children on roll at the present day. Headteacher Mr. B.J.Bridson.
